question.title: Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?
question.body:
This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

[image]

user_prompts:
QUESTIONS: {'P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('08a0bdcc-3cba-4a36-bf7f-f96b643b1321'), title='Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?', body='This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk does not become a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

excluding the Bitcoin Nashville 2024.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 12, 31, 23, 59, 59, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'P_or_Q': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('14faed52-4010-451f-9fd4-67a6401db1fe'), (2) Elon Musk is confirmed to appear unexpectedly at a significant cryptocurrency event in 2024, excluding the Bitcoin Nashville 2024.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 12, 31, 23, 59, 59, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=False), 'Q_and_not_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('e6a8a203-fc6d-40d6-befb-4808ca8ab81d'), title='Will both of the following occur: (1) Elon Musk makes a surprise appearance at any major cryptocurrency event in 2024 excluding the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, and (2) Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?', body='This question will resolve as Yes if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Elon Musk is confirmed to appear unexpectedly at a significant cryptocurrency event in 2024, excluding the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, and (2) Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 12, 31, 23, 59, 59, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'Q_given_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('03d8beb9-4e74-4bf0-89f0-3d3d1abcc2cf'), title='Given Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, will he make a surprise appearance at any major cryptocurrency event in 2024?', body='This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk does not become a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

This question will resolve as Yes if Elon Musk is confirmed to appear unexpectedly at a significant cryptocurrency event in 2024, excluding the Bitcoin Nashville 2024.

Resolution criteria: Resolves YES if Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 and is confirmed to appear unexpectedly at another major cryptocurrency event in 2024, excluding the Bitcoin Nashville 2024.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 12, 31, 23, 59, 59, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='conditional_binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None)}

GENERAL: Output your general reasoning and thought process.  Here you can be as detailed as you want, mentioning the reasoning of your predictions and how / why each prediction obeys the given consistency rules.  If there are multiple questions P, Q, you can also make comments on their independence or relationship with each other.

PROB: Output your probability estimates of each of the variables (P, Q, not_P, etc.).  Here, ONLY output the labels, their associated predictions, and NOTHING ELSE. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    P: 0.xx,
    not_P: 0.xx,
    P_or_Q: 0.xx,
    ...

CHECK: Go through each rule in CONSISTENCY RULES and check whether each rule is obeyed with your given predictions.  For each rule, first print the mathematical rule and the associated predicted values associated with it.  Then think VERY carefully about whether the outputs obey the mathematical rule. Then output whether it obeys the rule. At the end, print out a summary on whether all of the rules passed, or which ones failed. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    neg: P = 1- not_P, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    and:  max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), EQUATION is EVALUATION,
    ...
    {ALL consistency checks passed!} OR {failed_check_1, failed_check_2 ... consistency checks failed!

PROB: Now again output your probability estimates of each variable in a dict like format like before, but taking account and correcting any consistency violations that occurred.
        Note that changing the predicted probability of one value to satisfy one consistency rule will also affect consistency rules for others.  It is IMPERATIVE that any changes made still ensure all other consistency checks pass too.
        If there were no violations found, then simply output the same dict again.  Your output MUST look like and be formatted as follows.
        P: 0.xx,
        not_P: 0.xx,
        P_or_Q: 0.xx,
        ...
FLOAT: Now just output your probability estimate of P and nothing else as a decimal!
metadata.chain_of_thought:
RECEIVED

P: #Reasons P may or may not happen
not_P: #Reasons not_P may or may not happen
para_P: #Reasons para_P may or may not happen
Q: #Reasons Q may or may not happen
P_and_Q: #Reasons P_and_Q may or may not happen
P_or_Q: #Reasons P_or_Q may or may not happen
Q_and_not_P: #Reasons Q_and_not_P may or may not happen
Q_given_P: #Reasons Q_given_P may or may not happen

P: 0.73
not_P: 0.27
para_P: 0.73
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.83
Q_and_not_P: 0.10
Q_given_P: 0.32

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.73 = 1 - 0.27 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.73 = 0.83 + 0.23 - 0.33 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73, + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.73, 0.33) <= 0.83 <= min(1, 0.73 + 0.33) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.73 = 0.83 - 0.10 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.73 ≈ 0.23 / 0.32 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.73 = 0.73 is TRUE
ALL consistency checks passed!

Q: 0.33

Q: #Reasons Q may or may not happen

Q_and_not_P: 0.12
Q_given_P: 0.32

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.73 = 1 - 0.35 is FALSE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.73 = 0.71 + 0.23 - 0.33 is FALSE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73 + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.73, 0.33) <= 0.71 <= min(1, 0.73 + 0.33) is FALSE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.73 = 0.71 - 0.12 is FALSE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.73 ≈ 0.23 / 0.32 is TRUE

P: 0.73
not_P: 0.27
para_P: 0.73
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.83
Q_and_not_P: 0.10
Q_given_P: 0.32

0.73

RECEIVED

In this scenario, we are evaluating the probabilities of various events related to Elon Musk's attendance at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 and his potential surprise appearances at other cryptocurrency events in 2024. The key questions are: 1. Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 (P)? 2. Will he show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 (not_P)? 3. Is it possible that he will be absent from the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 (para_P)? 4. Will he make a surprise appearance at any major cryptocurrency event in 2024 (Q)? 5. Will both P and Q occur? 6. Will either P or Q occur? 7. Will both Q and not_P occur? 8. Given that he does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, will he make a surprise appearance at any major cryptocurrency event in 2024 (Q_given_P)? 

The independence of events is crucial in this analysis. P and not_P are mutually exclusive; if one occurs, the other cannot. Similarly, Q is independent of P and not_P, as they pertain to different events. However, P and Q can be related in the context of P_and_Q. 

For the probability estimates, I will consider the likelihood of Elon Musk's attendance based on historical behavior at similar events, public interest, and the significance of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024. 

1. For P (not showing up), I estimate a probability of 0.60 based on the possibility that he may have other commitments. 
2. For not_P (showing up), I estimate 0.40, as there is still a chance he could attend. 
3. For para_P, since it is essentially the same as not_P, I will estimate it at 0.60. 
4. For Q, I estimate a probability of 0.50 for a surprise appearance at another event, given his unpredictable nature. 
5. For P_and_Q, since both events can happen simultaneously, I estimate it at 0.30. 
6. For P_or_Q, the probability of either occurring, I estimate it at 0.70. 
7. For Q_and_not_P, I estimate it at 0.20, as both cannot happen at the same time. 
8. Finally, for Q_given_P, I assume that if he does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, the probability of him making a surprise appearance at another event is still 0.50. 

I will now summarize the probabilities for each event.

P: 0.60,
not_P: 0.40,
para_P: 0.60,
Q: 0.50,
P_and_Q: 0.30,
P_or_Q: 0.70,
Q_and_not_P: 0.20,
Q_given_P: 0.50

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.60 = 1 - 0.40 is FALSE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.60 = 0.70 + 0.30 - 0.50 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.60 + 0.50 - 1, 0) <= 0.30 <= min(0.60, 0.50) is FALSE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.60, 0.50) <= 0.70 <= min(1, 0.60 + 0.50) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.60 = 0.70 - 0.20 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.60 ≈ 0.30 / 0.50 is FALSE
para: P = para_P, 0.60 = 0.60 is TRUE

neg, and, cond consistency checks failed!

P: 0.50,
not_P: 0.50,
para_P: 0.50,
Q: 0.50,
P_and_Q: 0.25,
P_or_Q: 0.75,
Q_and_not_P: 0.20,
Q_given_P: 0.50

0.5

question.title: Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?
question.body:
This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk does not become a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

[image]

In this scenario, we are assessing the probabilities related to Elon Musk's potential appearances at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 and other cryptocurrency events in 2024. 

1. **P (Elon Musk not showing up at Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is a binary event and can be influenced by various factors, such as Elon Musk's schedule, public interest, and the significance of the event. Given his past behavior and the nature of such events, I estimate a moderate probability that he will not show up.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk showing up at Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This is the complement of P. If I estimate a 0.60 probability for P, then not_P would be 0.40. However, the estimates may need adjustment based on the interplay with other events.

3. **para_P (Possibility of absence from Bitcoin Nashville)**: This is essentially the same event as P, so I would assign it the same probability.

4. **Q (Surprise appearance at another cryptocurrency event)**: This event is independent of P and not_P. Given Elon Musk's unpredictable nature, I estimate a moderate chance of a surprise appearance at another event.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occurring)**: This event can only happen if Musk does not show up at Nashville and simultaneously makes a surprise appearance elsewhere. This is a more constrained probability and would be less than the individual probabilities of P and Q.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurring)**: This event is more likely than either P or Q occurring alone, so I would estimate this to be higher than the individual probabilities.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Both Q occurring and Musk showing up at Nashville)**: This scenario is logically impossible, as Q indicates a surprise appearance elsewhere while not_P states he is present at Nashville. Thus, this probability should be 0.

8. **Q_given_P (Q occurring given that P is true)**: This is a conditional probability that requires estimating the likelihood of Q happening if we know that P has occurred. This would likely be influenced by the same factors affecting Q, but may be slightly adjusted downwards due to the context of P being true.

Overall, I need to ensure that all these probabilities adhere to the consistency rules provided. The relationships between these events, especially the complementarity and conditional probabilities, are crucial for maintaining the integrity of my estimates.
